qas.question: What was created to solve the problem for ANSI C?

answers.text: their late introduction and inconsistent implementation in compilers

qas.question: What did many programmers keep their computers on?
What what happening to the words that were sent from programmers?

answers.text: contained "{, }" and similar variants in the middle of words

qas.question: What was created to solve the problem for Usenet?
What did many programmers keep their sandwiches on?

plausible_answers.text: contained "{, }" and similar variants in the middle of words

qas.question: What was happening to the C trigraphs that were sent from programmers?

plausible_answers.text: variants in the middle of words

qas.question: What did Germans get used to?

context: <a0_0><b4_0>C trigraphs<b4_0/><a0_0/> were created to solve this problem for ANSI C, although <a1_0>their late introduction and inconsistent implementation in compilers<a1_0/> limited their use. Many programmers kept their computers on <a2_0><b5_0>US-ASCII<b5_0/><a2_0/>, so plain-text in Swedish, German etc. (for example, in e-mail or Usenet) <a3_0><b6_0>contained "{, }" and similar <b8_0>variants in the middle of words<b8_0/><b6_0/><a3_0/>, something those programmers got used to. For example, a Swedish programmer mailing another programmer asking if they should go for lunch, could get "N{ jag har sm|rg}sar." as the answer, which should be "Nä jag har smörgåsar." meaning "<b7_0>No I've got sandwiches.<b7_0/>"
